# As a SQL expert with a willingness to assist users, you are tasked with crafting a PostgreSQL query for the Automatic Learning for the Rapid Classification of Events (ALeRCE) Database in 2023. This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables. It is crucial to pay attention to explicit conditions outlined by the user and always maintain awareness of the broader context.
ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.  
Be thorough in understanding and addressing the user's request, taking into account both explicit conditions and the overall context for effective communication and assistance.


# The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    mjd DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* time of detection in modified julian date */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* filter identifier  (1=g; 2=r; 3=i)*/
    pid FLOAT NOT NULL, /* program identifier */
    diffmaglim DOUBLE PRECISION, /* limiting difference magnitud */
    isdiffpos INTEGER NOT NULL, /* whether the difference is positive or negative */
    nid INTEGER, /* unique night identifier */
    ra DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred right ascension */
    dec DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred declination */
    magpsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* point spread function (psf) difference magnitude */
    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */
    magap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitude */
    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */
    distnr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to the nearest source in the reference image */
    rb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF real bogus score */
    rbversion VARCHAR, /* version of the ZTF real bogus score */
    drb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    drbversion VARCHAR, /* versio  of the ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    magapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude */
    sigmagapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude error */
    rfid INTEGER, /* identifier of the reference image used for the difference image */
    magpsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* apparent magnitude (corrected difference magnitude) */
    sigmapsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming point like source */
    sigmapsf_corr_ext DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming extended source */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s magnitude was corrected */
    dubious BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object is dubious or not */
    parent_candid BIGINT, /* identifier of the candidate where this information was generated (this happens if the given detection does not pass the real bogus filter, but a later detection does */
    has_stamp BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the candidate has an associated image stamp (same as before */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL /* identifier of the correction step */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_ndetection_oid ON detection USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* band or filter identifier (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    stellar BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether we believe the object is stellar */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s light curve has been corrected */
    ndet INTEGER NOT NULL, /* the object number of detection in the given band */
    ndubious INTEGER NOT NULL, /* the points in the light curve in the given band that we don’t trust  */
    dmdt_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* lower limit for the the rate of magnitude change at detection in the given band */
    dm_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* change in magnitude with respect to the last non detection at detection in the given band */
    sigmadm_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error in the change of magnitude w.r.t. the last detection in the given band */
    dt_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time between the last non detection and the first detection for the given band */
    magmean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmedian DOUBLE PRECISION, /* median difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmax DOUBLE PRECISION, /* maximum difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmin DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum difference magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the difference magnitude for the given band */
    maglast DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last difference magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst DOUBLE PRECISION, /* first difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmedian_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* median apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmax_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* maximum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmin_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    maglast_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection for the given band */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection for the given band */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* correction step id */
    saturation_rate DOUBLE PRECISION /* saturation level for the given band */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_dmdt_first ON magstat USING btree (dmdt_first);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_firstmjd ON magstat USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_lastmjd ON magstat USING btree (lastmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_magmean ON magstat USING btree (magmean);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_magmin ON magstat USING btree (magmin);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_magfirst ON magstat USING btree (magfirst);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_ndet ON magstat USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_maglast ON magstat USING btree (maglast);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_oid ON magstat USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE ps1_ztf ( /* information about the three closest sources in Pan STARRS */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    candid BIGINT NOT NULL, /* unique candidate identifier */
    objectidps1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* identifier of the closest source in pan starrs (ps) */
    sgmag1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ps g band magnitude */
    srmag1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ps r band magnitude */
    simag1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ps i band magnitude */
    szmag1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ps z band magnitude */
    sgscore1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ps star galaxy score */
    distpsnr1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to closest source in panstarrs */
    objectidps2 DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* identifier of the second closest source in pan starrs (ps) */
    sgmag2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-band PSF magnitude of second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    srmag2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* r-band PSF magnitude of second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    simag2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* i-band PSF magnitude of second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    szmag2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* z-band PSF magnitude of second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    sgscore2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy score of second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec: 0 <= sgscore <= 1 where closer to 1 implies higher likelihood of being a star */
    distpsnr2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [arcsec] */
    objectidps3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Object ID of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec */
    sgmag3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-band PSF magnitude of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    srmag3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* r-band PSF magnitude of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    simag3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* i-band PSF magnitude of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    szmag3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* z-band PSF magnitude of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    sgscore3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy score of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec: 0 <= sgscore <= 1 where closer to 1 implies higher likelihood of being a star */
    distpsnr3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [arcsec] */
    nmtchps INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Number of source matches from PS1 catalog falling within 30 arcsec */
    unique1 BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* Whether the first closest object has changed w.r.t the first alert */
    unique2 BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* Whether the second closest object has changed w.r.t the first alert */
    unique3 BOOLEAN NOT NULL /* Whether the third closest object has changed w.r.t the first alert */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, candid)
);



## DEFAULT CONDITIONS YOU NEED TO SET
### IF THE 'probability' TABLE is used, use always the next conditions, unless the user explicitly specifies different probability conditions.
- 'probability.ranking' = 1 ; this only return the most likely probabilities, if the user request all ranking probabilities, don't use it.
- 'probability.classifier_name='lc_classifier'
### IF THE 'feature' TABLE is used with 2 or more features, you need to take the following steps, because it is a transposed table (each feature is in a different row).
I. Create a sub-query using the 'probability' TABLE filtering the desired objects.
II. For each feature, you have to make a sub-query retrieving the specific feature adding the condition of its value, taking only the oids in the 'probability' sub-query with an INNER JOIN inside each 'feature' sub-query to retrieve only the features associated with the desired spatial objects.
III. Make an UNION between the sub-queries of each feature from step II
IV. Make an INTERSECT between the sub-queries of each feature from step II
V. Filter the 'UNION' query from step III selecting only the 'oids' that are in the 'INTERSECT' query from step IV
VI. Add the remaining conditions to the final result of step V, using the 'probability' sub-query from step I.
### GENERAL
### Important points to consider
- If the user doesn't specify explicit columns or information that is not in a column, choose all the columns, for example by using the “SELECT *” SQL statement, from ALL the tables used, including the ones from the sub-queries.
- Mantain the EXACT COLUMN names as they are in the database, unless the user explicitly asks you to do so in the request, giving you the new name to use. This is crucial for the query to work correctly.
- Mantain the exact class names as they are in the database, marked with single quotes, for example, 'SNIa'.


# If you need to use 2 or 3 tables, try using a sub-query or INNER JOIN over 'probability' TABLE or 'object' TABLE, or an INNER JOIN between 'probabbility' and 'object', or over an INNER JOIN between 'probability', 'object' and 'magstat', if it is necessary (priority in this order).
# Answer ONLY with the SQL query, do not include any additional or explanatory text. If you want to add something, add COMMENTS IN PostgreSQL format so that the user can understand.
# Finally, join all the steps in a final query, with the following format: 
```sql [FINAL QUERY HERE] ```
DON'T include anything else inside and after your FINAL answer.

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
**Decomposition Plan for the User Request:**

**Goal:**  
Return the objects classified as AGN that show variability in the r band, but have no detections or show no variability in the g band. Order the features by their value in ascending order, and the final query by oid.

---

### 1. **Identify AGN Objects**

- Use the `probability` table to select objects classified as 'AGN'.
- Apply the default conditions:
  - `probability.ranking = 1`
  - `probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`
  - `probability.class_name = 'AGN'`
- This subquery will yield the list of `oid` for AGN objects.

---

### 2. **Define Variability in the r Band**

- Use the `feature` table to identify AGN objects that show variability in the r band.
- Variability can be inferred from features such as:
  - `Std` (standard deviation of the light curve)
  - `ExcessVar` (intrinsic variability amplitude)
  - `Amplitude` (half the difference between the median of the maximum 5% and minimum 5% magnitudes)
- For the r band, `fid = 2`.
- Select oids from the AGN subquery (from step 1) that have a significant value in at least one of these features in the r band (e.g., `Std > 0`, `ExcessVar > 0`, or `Amplitude > 0`).
- Create a subquery for each feature indicating variability in the r band, joining with the AGN oids.

---

### 3. **Define No Detections or No Variability in the g Band**

- For the g band, `fid = 1`.
- "No detections" can be interpreted as:
  - No entries in the `detection` table for the object with `fid = 1`
  - Or, in the `feature` table, absence of features with `fid = 1`
- "No variability" can be interpreted as:
  - Features such as `Std`, `ExcessVar`, or `Amplitude` in the g band (`fid = 1`) are zero or below a threshold (e.g., `Std = 0`, `ExcessVar = 0`, `Amplitude = 0`)
- For each AGN oid, check:
  - Either there are no rows in the `feature` table for that oid with `fid = 1` and the variability features
  - Or, if such rows exist, their values are zero or below threshold
- This can be implemented using a NOT EXISTS or LEFT JOIN with NULL check, or by filtering out oids that have nonzero variability in the g band.

---

### 4. **Combine r Band Variability and g Band Non-variability/No Detection**

- Intersect the set of AGN oids with r band variability (from step 2) with the set of AGN oids with no g band detection or no g band variability (from step 3).
- This yields the final list of oids matching all criteria.

---

### 5. **Retrieve and Order Features**

- For the resulting oids, retrieve all features from the `feature` table.
- Order the features by their `value` in ascending order.
- Order the final result by `oid` as requested.

---

### 6. **Summary of Subqueries and Joins**

- **Subquery 1:** AGN oids from `probability` table (step 1)
- **Subquery 2:** AGN oids with r band variability (step 2)
- **Subquery 3:** AGN oids with no g band detection or no g band variability (step 3)
- **Final Set:** Intersection of subquery 2 and subquery 3 (step 4)
- **Final Output:** All features for these oids, ordered by `value` (ascending) and `oid` (step 5)

---

### 7. **Details for Each Step**

- Use INNER JOINs between `probability` and `feature` for filtering by AGN and r band variability.
- Use LEFT JOIN or NOT EXISTS to ensure no g band detection or no g band variability.
- Use INTERSECT to combine the sets as per the default conditions for the transposed `feature` table.
- Use ORDER BY for both `value` (ascending) and `oid`.

---

### 8. **Columns to Return**

- Since the user did not specify explicit columns, return all columns from the `feature` table for the selected oids.

---

**Summary:**  
The query will systematically:  
- Select AGN objects (from `probability`),  
- Filter for those with r band variability (from `feature`),  
- Exclude those with g band detection and variability (from `feature` and/or `detection`),  
- Retrieve all features for the resulting oids,  
- Order the features by their value (ascending) and the final result by oid.
# If there is SQL code, use it only as reference, changing the conditions you consider necessary.
# You can join some of the steps if you consider it better for the query. For example, if 2 or more use the same table and are not requested to be different sub-queries, then you can join them.

# Important Information for the query
External Knowledge: 0
Domain Knowledge: 0
 # User Request: ''Return the objects classified as AGN that show variability in the r band, but have no detections or show no variability in the g band. Order the features by their value in ascending order, and the final query by oid.''

# As a SQL expert with a willingness to assist users, you are tasked with crafting a PostgreSQL query for the Automatic Learning for the Rapid Classification of Events (ALeRCE) Database in 2023. This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables. It is crucial to pay attention to explicit conditions outlined by the user and always maintain awareness of the broader context.
ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.  
Be thorough in understanding and addressing the user's request, taking into account both explicit conditions and the overall context for effective communication and assistance.


# The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    mjd DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* time of detection in modified julian date */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* filter identifier  (1=g; 2=r; 3=i)*/
    pid FLOAT NOT NULL, /* program identifier */
    diffmaglim DOUBLE PRECISION, /* limiting difference magnitud */
    isdiffpos INTEGER NOT NULL, /* whether the difference is positive or negative */
    nid INTEGER, /* unique night identifier */
    ra DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred right ascension */
    dec DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred declination */
    magpsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* point spread function (psf) difference magnitude */
    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */
    magap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitude */
    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */
    distnr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to the nearest source in the reference image */
    rb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF real bogus score */
    rbversion VARCHAR, /* version of the ZTF real bogus score */
    drb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    drbversion VARCHAR, /* versio  of the ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    magapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude */
    sigmagapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude error */
    rfid INTEGER, /* identifier of the reference image used for the difference image */
    magpsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* apparent magnitude (corrected difference magnitude) */
    sigmapsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming point like source */
    sigmapsf_corr_ext DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming extended source */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s magnitude was corrected */
    dubious BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object is dubious or not */
    parent_candid BIGINT, /* identifier of the candidate where this information was generated (this happens if the given detection does not pass the real bogus filter, but a later detection does */
    has_stamp BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the candidate has an associated image stamp (same as before */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL /* identifier of the correction step */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_ndetection_oid ON detection USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* band or filter identifier (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    stellar BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether we believe the object is stellar */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s light curve has been corrected */
    ndet INTEGER NOT NULL, /* the object number of detection in the given band */
    ndubious INTEGER NOT NULL, /* the points in the light curve in the given band that we don’t trust  */
    dmdt_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* lower limit for the the rate of magnitude change at detection in the given band */
    dm_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* change in magnitude with respect to the last non detection at detection in the given band */
    sigmadm_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error in the change of magnitude w.r.t. the last detection in the given band */
    dt_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time between the last non detection and the first detection for the given band */
    magmean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmedian DOUBLE PRECISION, /* median difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmax DOUBLE PRECISION, /* maximum difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmin DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum difference magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the difference magnitude for the given band */
    maglast DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last difference magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst DOUBLE PRECISION, /* first difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmedian_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* median apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmax_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* maximum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmin_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    maglast_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection for the given band */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection for the given band */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* correction step id */
    saturation_rate DOUBLE PRECISION /* saturation level for the given band */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_dmdt_first ON magstat USING btree (dmdt_first);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_firstmjd ON magstat USING btree (firstmjd);

**Goal:**  
Return all objects classified as AGN (Active Galactic Nuclei) that show variability in the r band, but have no detections or show no variability in the g band. Order the features by their value in ascending order, and the final query by oid.

---

### 1. **Identify AGN Objects**

- Use the `probability` table to select objects (`oid`) classified as 'AGN'.
- Apply the default conditions:
  - `probability.ranking = 1`
  - `probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`
  - `probability.class_name = 'AGN'`
- This subquery will provide the list of oids for AGN objects.

---

### 2. **Define Variability in the r Band**

- Variability can be inferred from features in the `feature` table related to the r band (`fid = 2`).
- Common variability indicators include:
  - 'Std' (standard deviation of the light curve)
  - 'ExcessVar' (intrinsic variability amplitude)
  - 'Amplitude' (half the difference between the median of the maximum 5% and minimum 5% magnitudes)
- For this query, select objects with a significant value in at least one of these features in the r band. For example, 'Std' > 0 or 'ExcessVar' > 0 or 'Amplitude' > 0.
- Create a subquery for each feature in the r band (`fid = 2`), INNER JOINed with the AGN oids from step 1.

---

### 3. **Define No Detections or No Variability in the g Band**

- For the g band, `fid = 1`.
- "No detections" can be checked by the feature 'n_det' (number of detections in the alert light curve of a given band) being 0 or NULL.
- "No variability" can be checked by 'Std', 'ExcessVar', and 'Amplitude' being 0 or NULL in the g band.
- Create subqueries for each of these features in the g band, INNER JOINed with the AGN oids from step 1.
- For "no detections," select oids where 'n_det' is 0 or does not exist.
- For "no variability," select oids where 'Std', 'ExcessVar', and 'Amplitude' are 0 or NULL.

---

### 4. **Combine Variability and Non-Variability Conditions**

- For the r band, UNION the oids from the subqueries for 'Std', 'ExcessVar', and 'Amplitude' where the value is > 0.
- For the g band, INTERSECT the oids from the subqueries for 'n_det' = 0 or NULL, and 'Std', 'ExcessVar', and 'Amplitude' = 0 or NULL.
- The final set of oids should be those that are in the r band variability set AND in the g band non-variability/no-detection set.

---

### 5. **Retrieve and Order Features**

- For the resulting oids, retrieve all features from the `feature` table.
- Order the features by their `value` in ascending order.
- Order the final result by `oid`.

### 6. **Summary of Subqueries and Joins**

- **Step 1:** Subquery for AGN oids from `probability`.
- **Step 2:** Subqueries for r band variability features, INNER JOINed with AGN oids.
- **Step 3:** Subqueries for g band non-variability/no-detection features, INNER JOINed with AGN oids.
- **Step 4:** UNION and INTERSECT as per the rules for the transposed `feature` table.
- **Step 5:** Final selection of features for the filtered oids, ordered as required.

---

### 7. **Final Output**

This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */

    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */

    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/

    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */

);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */

---

### 3. **Define No Detections or No Variability in the g Band**

- For the g band, `fid = 1`.
- "No detections" can be checked by the absence of relevant features or by the absence of detections in the `detection` table for `fid = 1`.
- "No variability" can be checked by the variability features ('Std', 'ExcessVar', 'Amplitude') being zero or below a threshold in the g band.

  - Check if there are no rows in the `feature` table for that oid with `fid = 1` and the relevant variability features, OR
  - If such rows exist, ensure their values are zero or below a defined threshold.

### 4. **Combine r-band Variability and g-band Non-variability/No Detections**

- Intersect the set of AGN oids with r-band variability (Step 2) with the set of AGN oids with no g-band detections or no g-band variability (Step 3).

- **Subquery 1:** Select oids classified as AGN (from Step 1).

- **Subquery 3:** From Subquery 1, select oids with no g-band detections or no g-band variability (from Step 3).

Here is a detailed decomposition plan for generating the required PostgreSQL query, following the database schema, context, and advanced query requirements:

---

### 1. **Identify AGN Objects with High Classification Probability**
- **Table:** `probability`
- **Conditions:**
  - `class_name = 'AGN'`
  - `classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`
  - `ranking = 1` (default condition)
  - `probability > 0.6`
- **Output:** List of `oid` for objects classified as AGN with high confidence.

---

### 2. **Filter Objects with Light Curves Covering at Least One Year**
- **Table:** `object`
- **Condition:** 
  - `deltajd >= 365` (difference in days between last and first detection)
- **Join:** INNER JOIN with the AGN `oid` list from Step 1 to restrict to relevant objects.

---

### 3. **Select Objects with at Least 20 Detections in at Least One Band**
- **Table:** `feature`
- **Feature Name:** `n_det`
- **Condition:** 
  - `value >= 20`
- **Note:** Since `feature` is transposed, each row is a feature for an object and band.
- **Join:** INNER JOIN with the AGN `oid` list from Step 1.
- **Result:** List of `oid` and corresponding `fid` (filter id) where the detection count condition is met.

---

### 4. **Select Objects with Large Variations in Corrected Magnitudes**
#### 4.1. **Variation in g Band (fid=1) > 1 mag**
- **Table:** `feature`
- **Feature Names:** 
  - `min_mag` (minimum corrected magnitude in g band)
  - `max_mag` (maximum corrected magnitude in g band)
- **Condition:** 
  - Both features must be for `fid=1`
  - Both features must be for the same `oid`
- **Calculation:** 
  - Compute `delta_mag_g = max_mag - min_mag` for each `oid` in g band
  - Condition: `delta_mag_g > 1`
- **Join:** INNER JOIN with the AGN `oid` list from Step 1.

#### 4.2. **Variation in r Band (fid=2) > 0.5 mag**
- **Table:** `feature`
- **Feature Names:** 
  - `min_mag` (minimum corrected magnitude in r band)
  - `max_mag` (maximum corrected magnitude in r band)
- **Condition:** 
  - Both features must be for `fid=2`
  - Both features must be for the same `oid`
- **Calculation:** 
  - Compute `delta_mag_r = max_mag - min_mag` for each `oid` in r band
  - Condition: `delta_mag_r > 0.5`
- **Join:** INNER JOIN with the AGN `oid` list from Step 1.

#### 4.3. **Combine Variation Conditions**
- **Requirement:** Only select `oid` that satisfy both the g band and r band variation conditions.
- **Method:** 
  - Use INTERSECT between the sets of `oid` from 4.1 and 4.2.

---

### 5. **Combine All Feature-Based Conditions**
- **Method:** 
  - For each feature-based condition (Step 3, Step 4.1, Step 4.2), create subqueries for the relevant features and oids.
  - Use INTERSECT to ensure only oids that satisfy all feature conditions are selected.
  - Use UNION to collect all relevant feature rows for the selected oids.

---

### 6. **Retrieve Required Output Columns**
- **From `feature` Table:**
  - `oid`
  - `name`
  - `value`
  - `version`
  - `fid` (aliased as `feature_fid`)
- **From `object` Table:**
  - `meanra`
  - `meandec`
  - `ndet`
- **From `feature` Table (for min/max mag and delta_mag):**
  - For each band (g and r), retrieve `min_mag` and `max_mag` values, and compute `delta_mag` as `max_mag - min_mag` (aliased as `delta_mag`).
  - Include `fid` (aliased as `feature_fid`).

---

### 7. **Final Assembly**
- **Join:** 
  - INNER JOIN the filtered `oid` list (from Step 5) with the `object` table to get mean coordinates and detection count.
  - INNER JOIN with the `feature` table to get all required feature rows for the selected oids.
- **Select:** 
  - All required columns as specified in Step 6.
  - For each band, ensure the correct calculation and aliasing of `delta_mag`.
- **Distinct:** 
  - Ensure that each row in the result corresponds to a unique combination of `oid`, `feature`, and `fid`.

---

### 8. **Column Aliasing**
- **For filter id columns:** 
  - Alias as `feature_fid` (e.g., `feature.fid AS feature_fid`).
- **For delta_mag columns:** 
  - Alias as `delta_mag`.

---

### 9. **Summary of Subqueries and Set Operations**
- **Subqueries:**
  - AGN selection (Step 1)
  - Light curve duration (Step 2)
  - Detection count per band (Step 3)
  - Magnitude variation per band (Steps 4.1 and 4.2)
- **Set Operations:**
  - INTERSECT to enforce all feature-based conditions.
  - UNION to collect all relevant feature rows for the selected oids.

---

### 10. **Ensure Optimal Query Structure**
- **Indexes:** 
  - Use indexed columns for joins and filtering (`oid`, `class_name`, `ranking`, `classifier_name`, `value`, `fid`).
- **Avoid:** 
  - Filtering on non-indexed columns in large tables unless necessary.

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
Here is a detailed decomposition plan for generating the required PostgreSQL query, following the database schema, context, and advanced query requirements:

---

### 1. **Identify AGN Objects with High Classification Probability**
- **Table:** `probability`
- **Conditions:**
  - `class_name = 'AGN'`
  - `classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`
  - `ranking = 1` (default condition)
  - `probability > 0.6`
- **Output:** List of `oid` for objects classified as AGN with the required probability.

---

### 2. **Filter Objects with Light Curves Covering at Least One Year**
- **Table:** `object`
- **Join:** Use the `oid` from Step 1.
- **Condition:** 
  - `deltajd >= 365` (light curve covers at least one year)
- **Output:** List of `oid` that satisfy both AGN classification and time coverage.

---

### 3. **Select Objects with at Least 20 Detections in at Least One Band**
- **Table:** `feature`
- **Feature Name:** `n_det`
- **Condition:** 
  - `value >= 20`
- **Join:** Only consider `oid` from Step 2.
- **Output:** List of `oid` that have at least one band with 20 or more detections.

---

### 4. **Select Objects with Required Magnitude Variations in g and r Bands**
#### 4.1. **g Band: Variation > 1 mag (Corrected)**
- **Table:** `feature`
- **Feature Name:** `delta_mag_fid`
- **Band:** `fid = 1` (g band)
- **Condition:** 
  - `value > 1`
- **Join:** Only consider `oid` from Step 3.

#### 4.2. **r Band: Variation > 0.5 mag (Corrected)**
- **Table:** `feature`
- **Feature Name:** `delta_mag_fid`
- **Band:** `fid = 2` (r band)
- **Condition:** 
  - `value > 0.5`
- **Join:** Only consider `oid` from Step 3.

#### 4.3. **Combine g and r Band Variation Conditions**
- **Method:** 
  - For the transposed `feature` table, create two subqueries (one for each band/condition).
  - Use an `INTERSECT` to get `oid` present in both subqueries (i.e., objects meeting both g and r band variation requirements).

---

### 5. **Aggregate All Filters to Get Final List of oids**
- **Method:** 
  - The final list of `oid` is the intersection of all previous steps (AGN classification, time coverage, detection count, and both magnitude variation conditions).

---

### 6. **Retrieve Required Output Columns**
#### 6.1. **From `feature` Table**
- **Columns:** `oid`, `name`, `value`, `version`, `fid` (aliased as `feature_fid`)
- **Condition:** 
  - Only include features for the final list of `oid` from Step 5.

#### 6.2. **From `object` Table**
- **Columns:** 
  - `meanra`, `meandec` (mean coordinates)
  - `ndet` (total number of detections)
- **Join:** On `oid` from Step 5.

#### 6.3. **From `feature` Table for Magnitude Statistics**
- **Feature Names:** 
  - `min_mag` and `max_mag` for both g (`fid=1`) and r (`fid=2`) bands.
- **Columns:** 
  - For each band, retrieve `min_mag` and `max_mag` values, their `version`, and `fid` (aliased as `feature_fid`).
- **Join:** Only for `oid` from Step 5.

#### 6.4. **Calculate Magnitude Variations (delta_mag)**
- **Method:** 
  - For each band, compute `delta_mag = max_mag - min_mag`.
  - Alias the result as `delta_mag` for each band.

---

### 7. **Assemble the Final Output**
- **Columns to Return:**
  - `oid`
  - `name` (from `feature`)
  - `value` (from `feature`)
  - `version` (from `feature`)
  - `feature_fid` (from `feature`)
  - `meanra` (from `object`)
  - `meandec` (from `object`)
  - `ndet` (from `object`)
  - `min_mag` and `max_mag` (from `feature` for both bands)
  - `delta_mag` (computed for both bands)
- **Method:** 
  - Use appropriate `JOIN`s to combine data from `object` and `feature` tables for the selected `oid`s.
  - Ensure that the `feature` table is joined multiple times as needed to retrieve different features (e.g., `min_mag`, `max_mag`, `delta_mag_fid`, `n_det`).

---

### 8. **Apply Aliases and Formatting**
- **Alias `fid` columns as `feature_fid` in the output.**
- **Alias the computed magnitude difference as `delta_mag`.**
- **Ensure all columns are selected as per the user’s request.**

---

### 9. **(Optional) Order or Group Results**
- **If required, group by `oid` or order by a relevant column (e.g., `oid` or `delta_mag`).**

---

### 10. **Summary of Subqueries and Joins**
- **Subquery 1:** Select `oid` from `probability` with AGN, probability > 0.6, ranking=1, classifier_name='lc_classifier'.
- **Subquery 2:** Filter those `oid` in `object` with `deltajd >= 365`.
- **Subquery 3:** Filter those `oid` in `feature` with `name='n_det'` and `value >= 20`.
- **Subquery 4:** Filter those `oid` in `feature` with `name='delta_mag_fid'`, `fid=1`, `value > 1`.
- **Subquery 5:** Filter those `oid` in `feature` with `name='delta_mag_fid'`, `fid=2`, `value > 0.5`.
- **INTERSECT** subqueries 4 and 5 to get objects with required variations in both bands.
- **Final Join:** Use the resulting `oid` to join with `object` and `feature` tables to retrieve all requested columns, including calculation of `delta_mag` for each band.

This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */

### 4. **Select Objects with Large Variations in Corrected Magnitudes**

#### 4.2. **Variation in r Band**
- **Table:** `feature`

- **Band:**

- **Condition:**

- **Note:** 
  - Only consider features where the magnitudes are corrected.
- **Join:**

- **Requirement:**

### 5. **Combine All Filters**
- **Method:**

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    mjd DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* time of detection in modified julian date */

    pid FLOAT NOT NULL, /* program identifier */
    diffmaglim DOUBLE PRECISION, /* limiting difference magnitud */
    isdiffpos INTEGER NOT NULL, /* whether the difference is positive or negative */
    nid INTEGER, /* unique night identifier */
    ra DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred right ascension */
    dec DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred declination */
    magpsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* point spread function (psf) difference magnitude */
    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */
    magap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitude */
    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */
    distnr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to the nearest source in the reference image */
    rb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF real bogus score */
    rbversion VARCHAR, /* version of the ZTF real bogus score */
    drb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    drbversion VARCHAR, /* versio  of the ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    magapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude */
    sigmagapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude error */
    rfid INTEGER, /* identifier of the reference image used for the difference image */
    magpsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* apparent magnitude (corrected difference magnitude) */
    sigmapsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming point like source */

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */

    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection for the given band */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection for the given band */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* correction step id */

);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_dmdt_first ON magstat USING btree (dmdt_first);

### 1. **Identify the Main Selection Criteria and Output Columns**

- **Selection Criteria:**
  - Objects whose highest probability in the stamp classifier is for class 'SN'.
  - The first detection (in any filter) occurred between MJD 60188.0 and 60190.0 (i.e., first two days of September).
  - The object qualifies as a "fast riser" (first detection is brighter by at least 0.25 mag/day than the last non-detection in the same filter).
- **Output Columns:**
  - Object identifier (`oid`)
  - Probability in the stamp classifier (for class 'SN')
  - Probability in the light curve classifier (for the most likely class)
  - Filter ID (`fid`)
  - Image difference (from non_detection: `diffmaglim`)
  - Filter ID from magstat as `magstat_fid`
  - Initial rise estimate (rate of magnitude change at detection: `dmdt_first` from magstat)

---

### 2. **Subquery: Select Objects with Highest Probability for 'SN' in Stamp Classifier**

- From the `probability` table, select objects where:
  - `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'`
  - `class_name = 'SN'`
  - `ranking = 1` (highest probability for this classifier)
- Retrieve `oid` and `probability` (as `stamp_prob`).

---

### 3. **Subquery: Get the Most Likely Light Curve Classifier Probability**

- From the `probability` table, select for each `oid`:
  - `classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`
  - `ranking = 1`
- Retrieve `oid`, `probability` (as `lc_prob`), and `class_name` (as `lc_class`).

---

### 4. **Subquery: Filter Objects with First Detection in First Two Days of September**

- From the `object` table, select objects where:
  - `firstmjd >= 60188.0` and `firstmjd < 60190.0`
- Retrieve `oid` and `firstmjd`.

---

### 5. **Subquery: Identify Fast Risers**

- For each object and filter:
  - From `magstat`, retrieve:
    - `oid`, `fid`, `dmdt_first` (rate of magnitude change at detection), and other relevant columns.
    - Only consider rows where `dmdt_first >= 0.25` (fast riser definition).
- This requires that the first detection and last non-detection are in the same filter, which is already encoded in `magstat.dmdt_first`.

---

### 6. **Subquery: Retrieve Non-Detections for Selected Objects**

- From `non_detection`, select all non-detections for the oids identified in the previous steps.
- Retrieve `oid`, `fid`, `mjd`, and `diffmaglim`.

---

### 7. **Join All Relevant Information**

- INNER JOIN the results from steps 2, 3, 4, and 5 on `oid` to ensure all criteria are met.
- For each object, join with `non_detection` to get all non-detections.
- For each object and filter, join with `magstat` to get `magstat_fid` and `dmdt_first`.

---

### 8. **Select and Alias Output Columns**

- Select the following columns:
  - `object.oid`
  - `stamp_prob` (probability from stamp classifier for 'SN')
  - `lc_prob` (probability from lc_classifier for most likely class)
  - `non_detection.fid`
  - `non_detection.diffmaglim`
  - `magstat.fid` as `magstat_fid`
  - `magstat.dmdt_first` as the initial rise estimate

---

### 9. **Order and Limit Results**

- Order the results by `oid`.
- Limit the output to 100 rows.

---

### 10. **Summary of Query Structure**

- The main query will be a SELECT with multiple INNER JOINs:
  - Join the filtered `probability` (stamp classifier) subquery with the filtered `probability` (lc_classifier) subquery on `oid`.
  - Join with the filtered `object` subquery on `oid`.
  - Join with the filtered `magstat` subquery on `oid` and `fid`.
  - Join with `non_detection` on `oid` and `fid`.
- Apply all WHERE conditions as described above.

---

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);

CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
Here is a detailed decomposition plan for generating the required PostgreSQL query, step by step, with all necessary details and logic:

---

### 1. **Identify Relevant Tables and Columns**
- **object**: Contains object identifiers (oid), and first detection times (firstmjd).
- **probability**: Contains classification probabilities for each object, classifier, and class.
- **detection**: Contains detection events, including magnitude and time (mjd, magpsf, fid).
- **non_detection**: Contains non-detection events, including limiting magnitude and time (mjd, diffmaglim, fid).
- **magstat**: Contains per-filter statistics, including first detection time (firstmjd), filter id (fid), and magnitude change rate (dmdt_first).

---

### 2. **Filter Objects with First Detection in First 2 Days of September**
- Use the **object** table.
- Condition: `firstmjd >= 60188.0 AND firstmjd < 60190.0`

---

### 3. **Select Objects with Highest Probability for 'SN' in the Stamp Classifier**
- Use the **probability** table.
- Condition: 
  - `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'`
  - `class_name = 'SN'`
  - `ranking = 1` (highest probability for this classifier/class)
- Join with the filtered objects from step 2 on `oid`.

---

### 4. **Identify Fast Risers**
- For each object and filter:
  - Find the **first detection** (from **detection** table) in each filter (fid), matching the object's first detection time (firstmjd).
  - Find the **last non-detection** (from **non_detection** table) in the same filter, with `mjd < first detection mjd`.
  - Compute the rate: `(diffmaglim - magpsf) / (mjd_detection - mjd_non_detection)`
    - Only include if this rate is **>= 0.25 mag/day**.
- This requires:
  - For each object, for each filter, a subquery to get the first detection (by min(mjd)), and its magpsf.
  - For each object, for each filter, a subquery to get the last non-detection before the first detection (by max(mjd) < detection.mjd), and its diffmaglim.
  - Calculate the rate and filter for >= 0.25.

---

### 5. **Retrieve Probabilities in Both Stamp Classifier and Light Curve Classifier**
- For each qualifying object (from step 4):
  - Get the probability for the **stamp classifier** (`classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'`, `class_name = 'SN'`, `ranking = 1`).
  - Get the probability for the **light curve classifier** (`classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`, `ranking = 1`).
- Join these probabilities on `oid`.

---

### 6. **Retrieve Non-Detection Light Curve Data**
- For each qualifying object (from step 4):
  - Retrieve all **non-detection** entries (from **non_detection** table) for that object.
  - Include: `oid`, `fid`, `mjd`, `diffmaglim`.

---

### 7. **Retrieve magstat Information**
- For each qualifying object and filter (from step 4):
  - Retrieve from **magstat**: `oid`, `fid` (as `magstat_fid`), and `dmdt_first` (initial rise estimate).

---

### 8. **Assemble the Final Output**
- For each qualifying object, for each filter where it is a fast riser:
  - Output:
    - `oid`
    - Probability in **stamp classifier** (for 'SN')
    - Probability in **light curve classifier** (for ranking=1)
    - Non-detection light curve data: `fid`, `mjd`, `diffmaglim`
    - `magstat_fid` (from magstat)
    - `dmdt_first` (initial rise estimate)
- Order the results by `oid`.
- Limit the results to 100 rows.

---

### 9. **Detailed Subquery and Join Plan**
- **Step 9.1:** Subquery to get objects with first detection in the first 2 days of September (from **object**).
- **Step 9.2:** Subquery to get oids with highest probability for 'SN' in the stamp classifier (from **probability**), joined to step 9.1.
- **Step 9.3:** For each oid from step 9.2, for each filter:
  - Subquery to get the first detection (from **detection**) in each filter, matching the object's firstmjd.
  - Subquery to get the last non-detection (from **non_detection**) in the same filter, with `mjd < detection.mjd`.
  - Calculate the rate and filter for >= 0.25.
- **Step 9.4:** For oids and filters passing the fast riser criterion, join to:
  - **probability** for both classifiers (stamp and lc).
  - **non_detection** for all non-detections for that oid.
  - **magstat** for `dmdt_first` and `fid` as `magstat_fid`.
- **Step 9.5:** Select and output the required columns, order by `oid`, and limit to 100 rows.

---

### 10. **Summary of Output Columns**
- `oid`
- `stamp_classifier_probability` (for 'SN')
- `lc_classifier_probability` (for ranking=1)
- `fid` (from non_detection)
- `mjd` (from non_detection)
- `diffmaglim` (from non_detection)
- `magstat_fid` (from magstat)
- `dmdt_first` (from magstat, initial rise estimate)

---

### 11. **Ordering and Limiting**
- Order the final result set by `oid`.
- Limit the output to 100 rows.

---

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
Here is a detailed decomposition plan for generating the required PostgreSQL query, step by step, using the ALeRCE database schema and all the provided context and constraints:

---

### 1. **Identify the Main Selection Table and Columns**
- The main table for object identifiers is `object` (column: `oid`).
- The `probability` table is needed for classification probabilities (for both 'stamp_classifier' and 'lc_classifier').
- The `detection` table is needed to find the first detection (for date and magnitude).
- The `non_detection` table is needed to find the last non-detection before the first detection (for magnitude limit).
- The `magstat` table is needed for the filter ID and to estimate the initial rise.

---

### 2. **Filter Objects with First Detection in the First 2 Days of September**
- Use the `object` table to get `oid`.
- Use the `firstmjd` column in `object` to filter for objects with `firstmjd >= 60188.0` and `firstmjd < 60190.0`.

---

### 3. **Determine Fast Riser Status**
- For each object, in each filter:
  - Find the first detection in the `detection` table (minimum `mjd` for each `oid`, `fid`).
  - For that detection, get the `magpsf` (or `magpsf_corr` if corrected).
  - Find the last non-detection in the `non_detection` table for the same `oid` and `fid`, with `mjd` less than the first detection's `mjd` (maximum `mjd` less than first detection).
  - Get the `diffmaglim` from the last non-detection.
  - Calculate the time difference (`dt = detection.mjd - non_detection.mjd`).
  - Calculate the magnitude difference (`dm = non_detection.diffmaglim - detection.magpsf`).
  - Calculate the rate: `dmdt = dm / dt`.
  - Select only those where `dmdt >= 0.25`.

---

### 4. **Filter for Highest Probability in Stamp Classifier for Class 'SN'**
- Use the `probability` table:
  - Filter for `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'`.
  - Filter for `class_name = 'SN'`.
  - For each `oid`, select the row with the highest probability (i.e., `ranking = 1`).
- Only keep objects where the highest probability class in the stamp classifier is 'SN'.

---

### 5. **Retrieve Probabilities in Stamp Classifier and Light Curve Classifier**
- For each selected `oid`:
  - Get the probability for `class_name = 'SN'` and `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'` (with `ranking = 1`).
  - Get the probability for `classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'` (with `ranking = 1`), regardless of class.

---

### 6. **Retrieve Non-Detections (Light Curve) for Each Object**
- For each selected `oid`, retrieve all rows from `non_detection` (i.e., the light curve consisting only of non-detections).
- Include `oid`, `fid`, `mjd`, and `diffmaglim`.

---

### 7. **Retrieve magstat Information for Initial Rise Estimate**
- For each selected `oid` and filter (`fid`), retrieve from `magstat`:
  - `oid`, `fid` (as `magstat_fid`), and any relevant columns for the initial rise estimate (e.g., `dmdt_first`).

---

### 8. **Assemble the Final Output Columns**
- For each qualifying object, output:
  - `oid`
  - Probability in stamp classifier (`probability` table, `class_name = 'SN'`, `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'`)
  - Probability in light curve classifier (`probability` table, `classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`)
  - For each non-detection: `fid`, `mjd`, `diffmaglim`
  - For each magstat: `magstat_fid` (i.e., `magstat.fid`), `dmdt_first` (initial rise estimate)

---

### 9. **Join and Subquery Structure**
- Start with a subquery to select `oid` from `object` with `firstmjd` in the required range.
- Join to a subquery that filters for fast risers (using `detection` and `non_detection` as described).
- Join to `probability` for the stamp classifier (with `class_name = 'SN'`, `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'`, `ranking = 1`).
- Join to `probability` for the light curve classifier (`classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`, `ranking = 1`).
- Join to `non_detection` for the light curve.
- Join to `magstat` for the initial rise estimate.
- Use appropriate ON conditions for `oid` and `fid` as needed.

---

### 10. **Ordering and Limiting**
- Order the final results by `oid`.
- Limit the output to 100 rows.

---

### 11. **Summary of Steps/Subqueries**
1. Subquery: Select `oid` from `object` where `firstmjd` is in the first 2 days of September.
2. Subquery: For each `oid` and `fid`, find first detection and last non-detection, compute `dmdt`, filter for `dmdt >= 0.25`.
3. Subquery: For each `oid`, select from `probability` where `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'`, `class_name = 'SN'`, `ranking = 1`.
4. Subquery: For each `oid`, select from `probability` where `classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`, `ranking = 1`.
5. Join: For each qualifying `oid`, join to `non_detection` to get all non-detections.
6. Join: For each qualifying `oid` and `fid`, join to `magstat` to get `magstat_fid` and `dmdt_first`.
7. Assemble: Select required columns from all joined tables.
8. Order by `oid`, limit to 100 rows.

---

### 12. **Notes and Caveats**
- Ensure that all joins are INNER JOINs to enforce that only objects meeting all criteria are included.
- If an object has multiple filters qualifying, each combination should be included.
- If an object has multiple non-detections, each should be included (i.e., the result may have multiple rows per object).
- Use aliases for clarity in the final SELECT.

This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */

    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */

    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    mjd DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* time of detection in modified julian date */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* filter identifier  (1=g; 2=r; 3=i)*/
    pid FLOAT NOT NULL, /* program identifier */
    diffmaglim DOUBLE PRECISION, /* limiting difference magnitud */
    isdiffpos INTEGER NOT NULL, /* whether the difference is positive or negative */
    nid INTEGER, /* unique night identifier */
    ra DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred right ascension */
    dec DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred declination */
    magpsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* point spread function (psf) difference magnitude */
    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */
    magap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitude */
    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */
    distnr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to the nearest source in the reference image */
    rb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF real bogus score */
    rbversion VARCHAR, /* version of the ZTF real bogus score */
    drb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    drbversion VARCHAR, /* versio  of the ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    magapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude */
    sigmagapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude error */
    rfid INTEGER, /* identifier of the reference image used for the difference image */
    magpsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* apparent magnitude (corrected difference magnitude) */
    sigmapsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming point like source */
    sigmapsf_corr_ext DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming extended source */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s magnitude was corrected */
    dubious BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object is dubious or not */
    parent_candid BIGINT, /* identifier of the candidate where this information was generated (this happens if the given detection does not pass the real bogus filter, but a later detection does */
    has_stamp BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the candidate has an associated image stamp (same as before */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL /* identifier of the correction step */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_ndetection_oid ON detection USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* band or filter identifier (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    stellar BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether we believe the object is stellar */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s light curve has been corrected */
    ndet INTEGER NOT NULL, /* the object number of detection in the given band */
